article.para: Your computer consists of a number of connected devices, which are collectively known as computer hardware.

Ubuntu normally configures your hardware automatically, but there may be occasions when you need to make changes to settings relating to hardware yourself. This section provides information on tools which can be used to configure your hardware.

sect1.title: Restricted drivers
sect1.para: Some devices attached to your computer may need restricted drivers to be installed in order to work properly.

sect2.title: Why are some drivers restricted?
sect2.para: Most of the devices (hardware) attached to your computer should function properly in Ubuntu. These devices are likely to have unrestricted drivers, which means that the drivers can be modified by the Ubuntu developers and problems with them can be fixed.

Some hardware does not have unrestricted drivers, usually because the hardware manufacturer has not released details of their hardware which would make it possible to create such a driver. These devices may have limited functionality or may not work at all.

If a restricted driver is availble for a certain device, you can install it in order to allow your device to function properly, or to add new features. For example, installing a restricted driver for certain graphics cards may allow you to use more advanced desktop effects.

Some computers may not have any devices which can use restricted drivers, either because all of the devices are fully supported by unrestricted drivers or because no restricted drivers are yet available for the device.

caution.para: Restricted drivers are often maintained by the hardware manufacturer, and so cannot be modified by Ubuntu developers if there is a problem.

sect2.title: Enabling a restricted driver
sect2.para: To use a restricted driver for a device:

step.para: Press &restricted-manager;
Find the driver which you would like to enable and check the box in the Enabled column, next to its name
You will be asked to confirm that you want to enable the driver. Press Enable Driver
The restricted driver may have to be downloaded and installed.
You may need to restart your computer to finish enabling the driver

sect2.title: Disabling a restricted driver
sect2.para: If a restricted driver is causing problems, or you would just like to turn it off, follow the procedure below:

step.para: Press &restricted-manager;
Find the driver which you would like to disable and uncheck the box in the Enabled column, next to its name
You will be asked to confirm that you would like to disable the driver. Press Disable Driver
You may need to restart your computer to finish disabling the driver

sect1.title: Disks and partitions
sect1.para: This section provides instructions on how to handle disks and drives, such as removable hard disks.

sect2.title: Checking Free and Used Space
sect2.para:
To check the amount of free and used space on your computer, on your removable devices and on your file systems, do as follow:
Choose &computer;,
Select the desired device and right click on it,
Select Properties.
You will be present with a two color pie chart indicating the free and used space on that particular device.
The blue color indicates the free space, the yellow one indicates the used space. On the right of this chart there's a small legend with the exactly free and used space.

note.para: If you want to know the amount of free and used space of a removable device like a CD/DVD-ROM or a USB key, first mount that particular device.

sect3.title: Advanced Analysis
sect3.para: For a more accurate analysis of your filesystem, you can use Disk Usage Analyzer. To launch Disk Usage Analyzer, choose &baobab;, or from a terminal (&terminal;) type baobab and hit Return.
For analysing the entire filesystem, press Scan Filesystem form the toolbar, or for analysing only your home folder, press Scan Home.
For more information about, see Disk Usage Analyzer.

sect2.title: Partitioning a Device
sect2.para: To partition a disk in Ubuntu, either a hard disk or a removable device, the program &gnome-partition-editor; is needed.
To install &gnome-partition-editor;, install the gparted package (see Add Applications).
To launch &gnome-partition-editor; choose &gparted;, or from a terminal (&terminal;) type gksudo gparted and press Enter.

sect3.title: Freeing Space in a Partition
sect3.para:
To create a new partition inside an already partitioned device, first you have to resize the partition. If you already have free space, skip to .
Launch &gnome-partition-editor;.
Select the device to partition from the drop-down list at the top-right of the main window.
A list of partitions will appear. Select the desired partition and choose Partition unmount .
To resize the partition choose Resize/Move. The dialog Resize/Move will be shown. You can use the Free Space Following (MiB) spin box to choose how much space to free after this partition, or Free Space Preceding (MiB) to free space before this partition. Alternatively you can use the slider to adjust the partition size..
To apply the changes, click Resize/Move.

sect3.title: Creating a New Partition
sect3.para:
To create a new partition:
Select the device to partition from the drop-down list at the top-right of the main window.
A list of partitions will appear. Select the one called unallocated and click New.
From the Filesystem drop-down list choose the desired type of filesystem to use and click Add.
To apply all the changes made, click Apply.

sect2.title: Formatting a Partition
sect2.para: To format a partition in Ubuntu, the program &gnome-partition-editor; is needed.
To install &gnome-partition-editor;, install the gparted package (see Add Applications).
To launch &gnome-partition-editor; choose &gparted;, or from a terminal (&terminal;) type gksudo gparted and press Enter.

To format a partition, do as follows:
Launch &gnome-partition-editor;.
Select the device to partition from the drop-down list at the top-right of the main window.
A list of partitions will appear. Select the desired partition and choose Partition unmount .
Select the partition you want to format and choose Partition Format to and select from the list the type of filesystem to format the partition to.
To apply all the changes made, click Apply.

warning.para: Pressing Apply will cause all of the files on the partition to be permanently deleted.

sect2.title: What is Formatting?
sect2.para: To format a hard disk, a device or a partition means to prepare that particular device to be used for storing data.
The operation of formatting a hard disk or a partition, implies the applying of a specific format to that device: this format is the filesystem.

When you buy a disk usually it is not formatted, and you cannot use it for archiving data. When you format the device, you will notice that the free space in it is less than the original size. This is due to the fact that some space has to be used to make the device usable: this space is occupied by the filesystem.

sect2.title: What is a Filesystem?
sect2.para: The filesystem is a mechanism with wich files are archived and organised on a storing device such as a hard disk, and is an important part of an operating system. Without a filesystem, accessing and storing files would be impossible.

There are different types of filesystem. The most common are:
Ext2/Ext3: these are usually found on GNU/Linux operating systems. Ubuntu uses ext3 as its default filesystem.
FAT16, FAT32: these are Microsoft Windows filesystems found on older computers. If you want to share data between two computers, you would probably choose the FAT32 filesystem.
NTFS: this is Microsoft Windows new filesystem being used as the default one in new Windows versions.
HFS: this is Macintosh default filesystem.

sect2.title: What is a Partition?
sect2.para: A partition is a means of dividing a phisical device, such as a hard disk, into many logical devices.
Each logical device is seen by the operating system as a distinct device, and thus is treated as an independent disk.

sect2.title: Mounting and Unmounting Devices
sect2.para: For information about mounting and unmounting a device, see Using Removable Media

Pay attention when removing a device: always unmount it to avoid data loss. If you attempt to remove a device without unmounting it, you will get a message explaining how to properly unmount a device.

sect1.title: Laptops
sect1.para: This section contains information for people using Ubuntu on a laptop computer.

sect2.title: Suspending and hibernating laptops
sect2.para: In order to save battery power, you can put your laptop into one of a number of power-saving modes when you are not using it. The available modes are detailed below:

listitem.para: Suspending a laptop is like putting the computer to sleep. The computer will still be turned on and all of your work will be left open, but the laptop will use much less battery power. You can wake the computer by pressing a key or clicking the mouse.

Hibernating is turning the computer off completely while saving the current state of the computer (such as keeping all of your open documents). When you turn the computer back on after hibernating, all of your work should be restored as it was before hibernation. No power is used at all when the computer is hibernating.
Shutting down is turning the computer off completely, without saving the current state of the computer. No power is used at all when the computer is shut down.

Resuming is bringing the computer out of a power saving mode and back into normal operation. You can resume the computer from being suspended by pressing a keyboard button or by clicking the mouse. You can resume from being hibernated by pressing the power button on your computer.

sect2.para: You can manually put your computer into a power-saving mode by pressing &quit; and then pressing the appropriate button.

caution.para: Some computers may have problems going into certain power saving modes. The best way of checking if your computer can handle a power-saving mode is to try to switch into that mode and see if it behaves as you expected.

sect3.title: Fixing problems with suspending, hibernating and resuming
sect3.para: If your computer cannot suspend, hibernate or resume properly, there may be a number of things that you can try to get it working correctly.

listitem.para: Check the test report for your laptop, if one has been made (see ).
Ask for assistance through an Ubuntu support channel.

sect2.title: Power management settings
sect2.para: You may wish to change the power management settings of your laptop in order to help extend its battery life and reduce energy wastage.

step.para: Press &power-management;.
Change the settings as appropriate. Changes are applied instantly.

sect2.para: Displaying a screensaver may use more power than simply letting the screen go blank. Turning off the screensaver could slightly improve the battery life of your laptop.

step.para: Press &screensaver;.
Change the Screensaver theme to Blank screen. This will simply display a blank screen as a screensaver.

note.para: When your laptop is running on battery, one of the biggest drains on power is the display. Turning the brightness of the display down could improve battery life significantly; many laptops allow you to do this by pressing FnF7 several times.

sect2.title: Touchpads
sect2.para: Most laptop computers come with a touchpad, which is used to control the mouse pointer. There are many ways of changing the way that the touchpad behaves; follow the instructions below to install an easy-to-use tool for changing touchpad settings.

step.para: Install the gsynaptics package from the Universe repository (see Add Applications).
Press &terminal;.
Type the following, entering your administrator password when prompted:
Find the section which begins with the following:
Insert the following line into the section, before the line which reads EndSection:
Save your changes to the file and close all currently running applications, saving your work as you do so.
Press &quit; and select Log Out, and then log in again.
Press &touchpad; and change the touchpad settings to your liking. Changes should take effect immediately.

note.para: See the community support pages for more information on touchpads.

sect2.title: Finding laptop testing reports
sect2.para: Many laptops are regularly tested by the Ubuntu community to ensure that various features work correctly. The results of these tests are available for you to read, and may offer insight into any problems you might be experiencing with your laptop.

listitem.para: See the Laptop Testing community support pages for a full listing of available laptop tests.

sect2.para: You can participate in laptop testing yourself by contacting the Laptop Testing Team.
